page.title: 01Hemington
page.content: The name Hemington almost certainly derives from the division of land among angle-Saxon chieftains, in this case one Heming, and the church still has a Norman font and chancel arch, indicating the existence of an established settlement by the start of the 12th Century. Most local opinion holds that the great depopulation of Hemington parish occurred as a result of the Black Dealth and that prior to this there was an almost continuous swathe of development from Hemington through Hardington to laverton. the dating of later parts of what is a very fine parish church suggests however that the village itself was much larger even in the 15th and 16th centuries. High church farmhouse is the only remaining example of pre-18th century domestic architecture in the entire parish, though Upper row
